By BRUCE DRAKE
Science Magazine has recently
disclosed that Johns Hopkins has
been involved in bacteriologial
and chemical warfare research.
Subsequent News-Letter investigations have documented that
Hopkins is receiving substantial
sums of money for Defense research, much of it classified.
In an article in the January 13
issue of Science, Elinor Langer
claimed that between 1955 and
1963, Hopkins received over one

million dollars for bacteriological
warfare research. Miss Langer
told the News-Letter that she
had confirmed the existence of
such a contract with the University.
"BW Significance"
The contract was handled by
the Institute of Cooperative Research, headed by H. Ridgely
Warfield. The Institute manages
all government research contracts except for those made
with the Applied Physics Laboratory. The bacteriological warfare (BW) research project was
headed by Dr. Leighton Cluff.
The work was described as
"studies of actual or potential
injuries or illnesses, studies on
diseases of potential BW significance, and evaluation of certain

Moore's death elicited a strong

in

Living Memorial
Norman Reeves, treasurer of
the foundation, feels that the
Center is more than a memorial
to Moore,"It is a living memorial
that is being cultivated to fill a
void in this community."
The volunteers cite a passage
from Moore's book, The Mind in
Chains to renew their enthusiasm. Moore said, "I think of
all the problems over all the
earth and I wonder if I'll ever
really be able to do more than
my share to help the world.
Whether I go forward as Don

Polaris Program
In 1961, The Ballistics Lab concluded a five-year contract with
the Air Force. Mr. Gibson reported that "most of the work being
done is of a classified nature."
He also said of the lab's achievements that "the results influence
selection of the proper weapons
systems in military planning."
The Applied Physics Laboratory does a substantial amount
of military research for the Navy.
In 1964 and 1965, the Physics Lab
reported that it was working
with surface-to-air missiles to be
launched from ships or submarines. Hopkins is known for its
large part in the development of
the Polaris missile.
"Systems engineering continues
to occupy more and more of the
laboratory's effort," said R. E.
Gibson in 1962. Gibson is the
director of the laboratory.

Scorpio Introduces
Absurdity Overwhelms Campus RisingFtimMovement

Drama Review

By SETH FELDMAN
Watching the Johns Hopkins
production of the classic farce
Campus Elections is much like
Sitting among a swarm of bees.
There is a constant droning that
suddenly intensifies as the swarm
of identical performers flies
faster and faster, buzzes louder
and louder. At one point the
engrossed
becomes
Spectator
enough to fear being stung. But
the moment passes, the bees calm
down and the play ends with the
assurance that the same quality
Of the same honey will be perpetually produced at the same
rate.

This is not to say that Campus
Elections was poorly received by
Its audience. On the contrary, the
play may well prove to be a
worthy sequel to Hopkins, highly
successful Fall production of the
comedy Dirty Rush. Like Dirty
Rush, Campus Elections has all
the essentials for popular success.
Beneath a thin veneer of rationality the play is basically mindless, requiring little mental activity on the part of its audience.
Moreover, Campus Elections is a
loud and bright production which
gives its audience a feeling of
participation in a carnival like
atmosphere. Perhaps it wouldn't
be going too far to say that the
play is the off-Broadway answer

to such crowd pleasers as Hello
Dolly and Sound of Music. It's
that bad.
Exchange Program
In essence, Campus Elections
has no plot other than the slow
and painful exchange of titles between one class and the class
below it. The "action" begins at
various times and at various
places as each of the stereotyped
campus politicos is visited by his
semi-annual Joan of Arc revelation. The "action" ends with a
tc-mporary pause while each actor
recaps what he has done and
plans for his performance in the
next inevitable election.
Acting out this plot of no real
beginnings, no logical progression and no meaningful conclusion, the cast executes a near
perfect exercise in the Theater of
the Absurd. Reciting nothing but
their pointless sing-song dialogue,
several of the actors are actually
able to give the impression that
there is a certain real purpose
beneath the surface of all the
mundane repetition. One can almost believe that there are real
goals to be pursued and that
these goals can be attained despite the continual human ineptness of those who pursue them.
Unfortunately, it is impossible
to single out the better individual
performances of Campus Elections. The directors of the play

Paul De Man, chairman of
Cornell's Comparative Literature

Dr. De Man will head a branch
of the Humanities Center until
a Comparative Literature Department is created. It will be
two years, however, before Dr.
De Man joins the faculty since
he will be teaching in Munich,
Germany.

insist that their production be a
monument to anonymnity. Characters are never permitted to
establish themselves to the entire
audience at once. Nor are any of
the characters permitted to come
into face to face conflict and thus
make themselves known through
public confrontation. Instead,
each actor is identified by placards written in the same absurd
language as the dialogue. The
signs are complimented by the
masks each player carries to disguise his face, just as the dialogue disguises his thoughts—a
device that theatergoers have already seen in Eugene O'Neill's
Strange Interlude. However, unlike Strange Intelude, the characters in Campus Elections have
nothing but masks, their naked
faces being the most deceiving
masks of all.
Theater of Cruelty
In addition to its absurdity,
Campus Elections makes use of a
adopted
technique
particular
fi om the Theater of Cruelty. The
technique, known as "audience
intimidation", is administered by
the actors in a furious scene that
takes place near the end of the
play. Just as the audience is preparing for the climax, the players
charge off the stage and surround
individual spectators, plead with
them, apply the most subtle pressures and the grossest forms of
coercion. A general feeling of fear
and revulsion spreads throughout
the audience as individuals and
small groups are worked to a
fever pitch by the frenzied actors.
And then, quite suddenly, it is
over. Much faster than anyone
thought possible, a feeling of
relief falls over the crowd. We
wonder how and why we ever
became so excited. Everything is
now back to normal. Nothing has
changed and as the actors say
their final lines we begin to feel
sure that nothing ever will.
senselessness,
Pointlessness,
anonymnity, audience intimidation. Perhaps the best one can say
about the Johns Hopkins production of Campus Elections is that
it demonstrates to the legitimate
theater the value of these dramatic techniques. It is hoped that
the theater will take note of the
experiment, recognize the effectiveness of these methods and
consequently make every effort
to avoid their future use.

Hard To Digest
The Johns Hopkins News-Letter has consistently
mrived toward developing a strong, independent college
newspaper. We believe that a college newspaper must
be free from all forms of external control, both editorially and financially, to serve its readership well. Just
as we oppose administrative controls on the content of
college newspapers, so we believe that financial independence is a precondition for editorial autonomy.
In recent weeks, the Readers Digest Association,
Inc., through its subsidiary company, National Educational Advertising Services, from which the News-Letter
receives kis majority of advertisement, has invited college
newspapers to distribute a new semi-monthly puld/icalion, Cainpus Courier, as a regular supplement, beginning in late September. Campus Courier will be published by Readers Digest Association, Inc.; for distributing the supplement, college newspapers will be paid a
substantial sum by Readers Digest Association, Inc.
Included in the contents of a dummy issue of
Campus Courier, sent to several college newspapers, were
an article on early marriage by Margaret Mead, a color
spread on the surfing scene, and a reprinted article by
Vice President Humphrey on his father ("The first time
I ever saw my father weep. ..."). In effect Campus
Courier is a slick, ehildish imitation of the already
childish Reader's Digest.
Over fifteen college newspapers with a total circulation of more than 150,000 circulation have already
turned down the offer to distribute Campus Courier.
In a statement issued on April 14, several college editors charged that insertation of Campus Courier in their
issues would endanger their papers both editorially and
financially.
The News-Letter endorses the position of the editors
who have rejected the Readers Digest Association, Inc.,
offer to distribute Campus Courier. We believe that distribution of the supplement by college newspapers
would be detrimental to the interests of the college press
In the following ways:
1. The Readers Digest Association,Inc., has said that
an editor may refuse to distribute any issue of Campus
Courier containing objectionable material.But if an editor
has planned his budget for the year in anticipation of
distributing Campus Courier, his ability to reject a particular issue of the supplement will he effectively limited.
Should he turn down an issue of The Campus Courier,
he will have to print fewer pages of his newspaper because of the loss of budgeted revenue. Hence, acceptance
of the Readers Digest Association, Inc., offer of Campus
Courier will constrain the editorial freedom of this newspapers editors.
2. Rather than channeling advertising to the
Campus Courier, the Readers Digest Association, Inc.,
the owner of National Educational Advertising Services,
would further the News-Letter's interests more directly
by selling more advertising to it, with no strings
attached.
3. We believe that the long-run strength of the
News-Letter depends upon the efforts of its editors and
business managers themselves to improve the newspaper, both editorially and financially. Projects such as
Campus Courier will instead increase the dependence
upon external organizations, a situation whidi poses a
long-term threat to the freedom of the college press.

By FRED RAIMI
The quality that makesMstislay
Rostropovich the greatest instrumentalist of this generation is not
his technical mastery of the cello,
and it is not simply the profundity of his musicianship. It is
rather that he understands fully
the power of music, and utilizes
all his ability to convey it to his
listeners.
From the moment Rostropovich sets his bow on the string,
one realizes that there is an artist
in complete control of his instrument. The next revelation is the
beauty and endless variety of the
sounds produced by his cello—
from the deep, godlike utterances
of the Brahms sonata to the rich
sonorities of the Bach suite to
the wolf-whistle and virtuoso
guitar effects in the Britten
sonata. One expects to watch brilliant technical feats and to hear
beautiful sounds from a virtuoso.
But Rostropovich offers much
more than this. His demeanor on
stage and his rapport with the
sounds he produces seem to say
to the audience,"The music I am
playing expresses all that is noble
and good in men. I feel it deeply
and sincerely, and I want you to
experience it too. Listen to me
and watch me."

'United States.

Winless Trackers Varsity Batsmen
Face ToughestFoe Aim at 500 Mark
By JEFF CHLEBNIKOW
Though they haven't scored
yet in the win column, the Hopkins track team :s preparing for
their toughest meet against
Towson State tomorrow.
In clashes with such foes as
Swarthmore, Franklin & Marshall, Lebanon Valley, Gettysburg, Albright, - Ursinus, and
Dickinson, "individual performances highlighted the days," says
Coach Don Masken as he cites
the play of Tom Faust, who leads
In the javelin throw, Junior Bill
Pump, outstanding in pole vault
besides competing in the 440yard low hurdles, and senior captain Dave Strobel, the defending
Mason-Dixon champion discus
thrower.
All Work Hard
According to Coach Masken,
"there isn't anybody on the varsity team who doesn't work." He
also stated that "the meets have
gotten harder but the team has
Improved, although its size has
decreased."
In the triple meet with Swarthmore and F & M, the Blue Jays
scored 21, after which they produced 213/
4 points against Gettysburg and Albright and 23 against
Ursinus and Dickinson, showing
definite progress.
Everybody Competes
Everybody on the track team
competes in at least two events.
This fact is emphasized by the
performances of such members
as sophomore Paul Carlson, who
is the top quarter-mile man be-

CHUNG'S

sides running the 440 intermediate hurdles and relays; sophomore John Gardner, contending
in the half-mile and full mile
and usually placing; "steadily
improving" senior Pete Rowny,
high hurdling and jumping, and
sophomore Al Goldberg, who has
placed in every meet in either
the 220 yard dash or 100 yard
dash.
Other members of the squad
Include sophomore Torn O'Dea
(100 yard dash and broad jump),
sophomore Connie Talbot (440
yards and relay team), junior
Cliff Cyr (2 mile), sophomore
Larry Smith (one and two mile),
sophomore Jim Bernstein (broad
jump and triple jump), junior
Jerry Danoff (880 yard run), and
sophomore George Vrablic (880
yard run and weights).
Towson Tomorrow
Tomorrow the Blue Jay cindermen host Towson State Teachers
College, who Coach Masken considers to be "by far the best we'll
come up against this year." The
meet will begin at 2:00 P.M.
After Towson, the season should
be easier as opponents will decline relatively in strength. On
Wednesday, May 3, the Jays go
(Continued on Page 7)

In Shoreman Tilt
The varsity baseball team,
sporting two recent wins, heads
into an away contest with Washington College tomorrow with its
hopes for a winning season considerably revivified.
The Hopkins nine, 3-5 as of
Wednesday, rode the arms of
Eric Javel and Hal Thorne, (who
hurled a two-hitter) to 5-3 and
11-0 triumphs over Ursinus (5-1
previously) and Catholic University during the past week, and
soph Dave Brainerd—out to continue a string of 17 scoreless
innings by Jay pitchers—was to
start against PMC (a 3-1 winner
over Ursinus) yesterday. After
Washington, the team hosts
Loyola (over whom it previously
triumphed 8-1) Tuesday, May 2.
The Homewood squad's earlyseason difficulties—coming in the
face of both optimistic pre-season predictions and decisive cumulative statistical advantages
over its opponents—have appeared a bit anomalous to Coach
Gary Barrette. The Jay diamond
mentor, itemizing the misleading
figures, has made some attempt

ForArmyCampaign
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Unbeaten in seven starts, the
varsity lacrosse team gets its first
major collegiate test—and meets
an opponent with decided national aspirations of its own—
tomorrow when it journeys to
West Point to face an experienced and sizable Army contingent. The game, which begins at
2:15 P.M., will be broadcast live
over WJHU.
The Cadets, 4-0 thus far, have
lost but two starters from the
group that triumphed 6-3 at
Homewood a year ago, and—with
19 seniors on the roster, eleven of
them concentrated among the
opening array and first three
midfields—appear to be engaged
In a this-year-or-never drive for
the
collegiate
championship.
They are rated by Jay scout Alex
Sotir as "capable of winning two
of their three big games (Hopkins, Navy, and Maryland)."
On the basis of Army's wins12-1, 11-9, 14-6, and 19-4 decisions over, respectively, Yale,
Rutgers, Princeton, and Hofstra
— and the comparative scores
produced thereby, Sotir's evaluation would appeai well-founded.
Hopkins defeated Yale 16-6
(after leading 15-1 entering the
fourth quarter) and Princeton
12-2.
Army Big
Perhaps — aside from experience — the dominant features of
the current Cadet aggregation
are its size and balance. The
attack, composed of 6-2, 185pound senior Chris Pettit (second
team All-America in '66 and still
the top Army offensive threat),
5'-9, 175-pound senior Ray Enners (a versatile performer who
teams well with Pettit), and 6-1,
185-pound junior Tom Rider;
and midfields (the first three of
whicth average six feet and 185
pounds per man) seemingly display these qualities to some degree.
The defense—headed by senior
footballers Dave Rivers (6-2,
215) and Tom Schwartz (6-3,
210), who team with 6-2, 190pound junior Brian Untermahlen
— is generally well-rated by
Sotir, and is much strengthened
by the presence of junior goalie

,‘•

Don Workman, whom Jay mentor Bob Scott regarded as the
equal in ability of any collegiate
netman faced by his team this
year.
Aussie Nationals Here
On Tuesday, May 2, the Australian National Lacrosse Team,
on its way to a mid-May international competition in Toronto,
will visit Homewood field for a
3:00 P.M. exhibition. The Aussies
—about whose rules and style of
play little is known—will face
the University Club and Navy on
succeeding days.
Last week's Jay triumph, a
14-3 decision over the UniversitY
of Pennsylvania, was a routine
enough affair, as the Homewood
squad moved to a 5-1 half-time
lead, and then put the issue totally out of doubt with a 6-1
third quarter spurt. The game
statistics were just as predictable, showing Hopkins with an
84-48 lead in ground balls, a
65-19 shot margin, and a 14 for
20 faceoff performance.
Offensive Efforts
Joe Cowan (two goals, three
assists, and nine ground balls),
Downy McCarty (2-3-2), and
Jerry Schnydman (1-3-11) led
the offensive efforts, while Phil
Kneip (2-1-5), Bob Carter (2-05), and Phil Parthemore (2-0-5)
did their share. Cowan, with 15
goals and 24 assists, was, as of
Tuesday, second in the state in
total points; Kneip (21 and 4)
was seventh, while tied with
Washington's Jim Chalfant and
Carl Ortman in the former department.
The Hopkins midfield situation, while hardly as marked bY
injuries as in previous weeks, still
has a slightly unsettled look.
Wayne Towns is the only regular
who definitely will not see action,
but the'second and third contingents—bothered by a variety of
nagging injuries—are uncertain.
Scott commented on the good
performances turned in by members (Steve Latson, Will Scroggs,
Wes Bachur. and Parthemore) of
these two groups in past weeks.

Drama Review

By SETH FELDMAN
Watching the Johns Hopkins
production of the classic farce
Campus Elections is much like
Sitting among a swarm of bees.
There is a constant droning that
suddenly intensifies as the swarm
of identical performers flies
faster and faster, buzzes louder
and louder. At one point the
engrossed
becomes
Spectator
enough to fear being stung. But
the moment passes, the bees calm
down and the play ends with the
assurance that the same quality
Of the same honey will be perpetually produced at the same
rate.

This is not to say that Campus
Elections was poorly received by
Its audience. On the contrary, the
play may well prove to be a
worthy sequel to Hopkins, highly
successful Fall production of the
comedy Dirty Rush. Like Dirty
Rush, Campus Elections has all
the essentials for popular success.
Beneath a thin veneer of rationality the play is basically mindless, requiring little mental activity on the part of its audience.
Moreover, Campus Elections is a
loud and bright production which
gives its audience a feeling of
participation in a carnival like
atmosphere. Perhaps it wouldn't
be going too far to say that the
play is the off-Broadway answer

to such crowd pleasers as Hello
Dolly and Sound of Music. It's
that bad.
Exchange Program
In essence, Campus Elections
has no plot other than the slow
and painful exchange of titles between one class and the class
below it. The "action" begins at
various times and at various
places as each of the stereotyped
campus politicos is visited by his
semi-annual Joan of Arc revelation. The "action" ends with a
tc-mporary pause while each actor
recaps what he has done and
plans for his performance in the
next inevitable election.
Acting out this plot of no real
beginnings, no logical progression and no meaningful conclusion, the cast executes a near
perfect exercise in the Theater of
the Absurd. Reciting nothing but
their pointless sing-song dialogue,
several of the actors are actually
able to give the impression that
there is a certain real purpose
beneath the surface of all the
mundane repetition. One can almost believe that there are real
goals to be pursued and that
these goals can be attained despite the continual human ineptness of those who pursue them.
Unfortunately, it is impossible
to single out the better individual
performances of Campus Elections. The directors of the play

insist that their production be a
monument to anonymnity. Characters are never permitted to
establish themselves to the entire
audience at once. Nor are any of
the characters permitted to come
into face to face conflict and thus
make themselves known through
public confrontation. Instead,
each actor is identified by placards written in the same absurd
language as the dialogue. The
signs are complimented by the
masks each player carries to disguise his face, just as the dialogue disguises his thoughts—a
device that theatergoers have already seen in Eugene O'Neill's
Strange Interlude. However, unlike Strange Intelude, the characters in Campus Elections have
nothing but masks, their naked
faces being the most deceiving
masks of all.
Theater of Cruelty
In addition to its absurdity,
Campus Elections makes use of a
adopted
technique
particular
fi om the Theater of Cruelty. The
technique, known as "audience
intimidation", is administered by
the actors in a furious scene that
takes place near the end of the
play. Just as the audience is preparing for the climax, the players
charge off the stage and surround
individual spectators, plead with
them, apply the most subtle pressures and the grossest forms of
coercion. A general feeling of fear
and revulsion spreads throughout
the audience as individuals and
small groups are worked to a
fever pitch by the frenzied actors.
And then, quite suddenly, it is
over. Much faster than anyone
thought possible, a feeling of
relief falls over the crowd. We
wonder how and why we ever
became so excited. Everything is
now back to normal. Nothing has
changed and as the actors say
their final lines we begin to feel
sure that nothing ever will.
senselessness,
Pointlessness,
anonymnity, audience intimidation. Perhaps the best one can say
about the Johns Hopkins production of Campus Elections is that
it demonstrates to the legitimate
theater the value of these dramatic techniques. It is hoped that
the theater will take note of the
experiment, recognize the effectiveness of these methods and
consequently make every effort
to avoid their future use.

Hard To Digest
The Johns Hopkins News-Letter has consistently
mrived toward developing a strong, independent college
newspaper. We believe that a college newspaper must
be free from all forms of external control, both editorially and financially, to serve its readership well. Just
as we oppose administrative controls on the content of
college newspapers, so we believe that financial independence is a precondition for editorial autonomy.
In recent weeks, the Readers Digest Association,
Inc., through its subsidiary company, National Educational Advertising Services, from which the News-Letter
receives kis majority of advertisement, has invited college
newspapers to distribute a new semi-monthly puld/icalion, Cainpus Courier, as a regular supplement, beginning in late September. Campus Courier will be published by Readers Digest Association, Inc.; for distributing the supplement, college newspapers will be paid a
substantial sum by Readers Digest Association, Inc.
Included in the contents of a dummy issue of
Campus Courier, sent to several college newspapers, were
an article on early marriage by Margaret Mead, a color
spread on the surfing scene, and a reprinted article by
Vice President Humphrey on his father ("The first time
I ever saw my father weep. ..."). In effect Campus
Courier is a slick, ehildish imitation of the already
childish Reader's Digest.
Over fifteen college newspapers with a total circulation of more than 150,000 circulation have already
turned down the offer to distribute Campus Courier.
In a statement issued on April 14, several college editors charged that insertation of Campus Courier in their
issues would endanger their papers both editorially and
financially.
The News-Letter endorses the position of the editors
who have rejected the Readers Digest Association, Inc.,
offer to distribute Campus Courier. We believe that distribution of the supplement by college newspapers
would be detrimental to the interests of the college press
In the following ways:
1. The Readers Digest Association,Inc., has said that
an editor may refuse to distribute any issue of Campus
Courier containing objectionable material.But if an editor
has planned his budget for the year in anticipation of
distributing Campus Courier, his ability to reject a particular issue of the supplement will he effectively limited.
Should he turn down an issue of The Campus Courier,
he will have to print fewer pages of his newspaper because of the loss of budgeted revenue. Hence, acceptance
of the Readers Digest Association, Inc., offer of Campus
Courier will constrain the editorial freedom of this newspapers editors.
2. Rather than channeling advertising to the
Campus Courier, the Readers Digest Association, Inc.,
the owner of National Educational Advertising Services,
would further the News-Letter's interests more directly
by selling more advertising to it, with no strings
attached.
3. We believe that the long-run strength of the
News-Letter depends upon the efforts of its editors and
business managers themselves to improve the newspaper, both editorially and financially. Projects such as
Campus Courier will instead increase the dependence
upon external organizations, a situation whidi poses a
long-term threat to the freedom of the college press.

By FRED RAIMI
The quality that makesMstislay
Rostropovich the greatest instrumentalist of this generation is not
his technical mastery of the cello,
and it is not simply the profundity of his musicianship. It is
rather that he understands fully
the power of music, and utilizes
all his ability to convey it to his
listeners.
From the moment Rostropovich sets his bow on the string,
one realizes that there is an artist
in complete control of his instrument. The next revelation is the
beauty and endless variety of the
sounds produced by his cello—
from the deep, godlike utterances
of the Brahms sonata to the rich
sonorities of the Bach suite to
the wolf-whistle and virtuoso
guitar effects in the Britten
sonata. One expects to watch brilliant technical feats and to hear
beautiful sounds from a virtuoso.
But Rostropovich offers much
more than this. His demeanor on
stage and his rapport with the
sounds he produces seem to say
to the audience,"The music I am
playing expresses all that is noble
and good in men. I feel it deeply
and sincerely, and I want you to
experience it too. Listen to me
and watch me."

Feldman, Jim Forer, Pete Kahn,

Hurwitz.

the close of their 1967 campaign.

Winless Trackers Varsity Batsmen
Face ToughestFoe Aim at 500 Mark
By JEFF CHLEBNIKOW
Though they haven't scored
yet in the win column, the Hopkins track team :s preparing for
their toughest meet against
Towson State tomorrow.
In clashes with such foes as
Swarthmore, Franklin & Marshall, Lebanon Valley, Gettysburg, Albright, - Ursinus, and
Dickinson, "individual performances highlighted the days," says
Coach Don Masken as he cites
the play of Tom Faust, who leads
In the javelin throw, Junior Bill
Pump, outstanding in pole vault
besides competing in the 440yard low hurdles, and senior captain Dave Strobel, the defending
Mason-Dixon champion discus
thrower.
All Work Hard
According to Coach Masken,
"there isn't anybody on the varsity team who doesn't work." He
also stated that "the meets have
gotten harder but the team has
Improved, although its size has
decreased."
In the triple meet with Swarthmore and F & M, the Blue Jays
scored 21, after which they produced 213/
4 points against Gettysburg and Albright and 23 against
Ursinus and Dickinson, showing
definite progress.
Everybody Competes
Everybody on the track team
competes in at least two events.
This fact is emphasized by the
performances of such members
as sophomore Paul Carlson, who
is the top quarter-mile man be-

CHUNG'S

sides running the 440 intermediate hurdles and relays; sophomore John Gardner, contending
in the half-mile and full mile
and usually placing; "steadily
improving" senior Pete Rowny,
high hurdling and jumping, and
sophomore Al Goldberg, who has
placed in every meet in either
the 220 yard dash or 100 yard
dash.
Other members of the squad
Include sophomore Torn O'Dea
(100 yard dash and broad jump),
sophomore Connie Talbot (440
yards and relay team), junior
Cliff Cyr (2 mile), sophomore
Larry Smith (one and two mile),
sophomore Jim Bernstein (broad
jump and triple jump), junior
Jerry Danoff (880 yard run), and
sophomore George Vrablic (880
yard run and weights).
Towson Tomorrow
Tomorrow the Blue Jay cindermen host Towson State Teachers
College, who Coach Masken considers to be "by far the best we'll
come up against this year." The
meet will begin at 2:00 P.M.
After Towson, the season should
be easier as opponents will decline relatively in strength. On
Wednesday, May 3, the Jays go

StickersPsyched Up
ForArmyCampaign
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Unbeaten in seven starts, the
varsity lacrosse team gets its first
major collegiate test—and meets
an opponent with decided national aspirations of its own—
tomorrow when it journeys to
West Point to face an experienced and sizable Army contingent. The game, which begins at
2:15 P.M., will be broadcast live
over WJHU.
The Cadets, 4-0 thus far, have
lost but two starters from the
group that triumphed 6-3 at
Homewood a year ago, and—with
19 seniors on the roster, eleven of
them concentrated among the
opening array and first three
midfields—appear to be engaged
In a this-year-or-never drive for
the
collegiate
championship.
They are rated by Jay scout Alex
Sotir as "capable of winning two
of their three big games (Hopkins, Navy, and Maryland)."
On the basis of Army's wins12-1, 11-9, 14-6, and 19-4 decisions over, respectively, Yale,
Rutgers, Princeton, and Hofstra
— and the comparative scores
produced thereby, Sotir's evaluation would appeai well-founded.
Hopkins defeated Yale 16-6
(after leading 15-1 entering the
fourth quarter) and Princeton
12-2.
Army Big
Perhaps — aside from experience — the dominant features of
the current Cadet aggregation
are its size and balance. The
attack, composed of 6-2, 185pound senior Chris Pettit (second
team All-America in '66 and still
the top Army offensive threat),
5'-9, 175-pound senior Ray Enners (a versatile performer who
teams well with Pettit), and 6-1,
185-pound junior Tom Rider;
and midfields (the first three of
whicth average six feet and 185
pounds per man) seemingly display these qualities to some degree.
The defense—headed by senior
footballers Dave Rivers (6-2,
215) and Tom Schwartz (6-3,
210), who team with 6-2, 190pound junior Brian Untermahlen
— is generally well-rated by
Sotir, and is much strengthened
by the presence of junior goalie

,‘•

Don Workman, whom Jay mentor Bob Scott regarded as the
equal in ability of any collegiate
netman faced by his team this
year.
Aussie Nationals Here
On Tuesday, May 2, the Australian National Lacrosse Team,
on its way to a mid-May international competition in Toronto,
will visit Homewood field for a
3:00 P.M. exhibition. The Aussies
—about whose rules and style of
play little is known—will face
the University Club and Navy on
succeeding days.
Last week's Jay triumph, a
14-3 decision over the UniversitY
of Pennsylvania, was a routine
enough affair, as the Homewood
squad moved to a 5-1 half-time
lead, and then put the issue totally out of doubt with a 6-1
third quarter spurt. The game
statistics were just as predictable, showing Hopkins with an
84-48 lead in ground balls, a
65-19 shot margin, and a 14 for
20 faceoff performance.
Offensive Efforts
Joe Cowan (two goals, three
assists, and nine ground balls),
Downy McCarty (2-3-2), and
Jerry Schnydman (1-3-11) led
the offensive efforts, while Phil
Kneip (2-1-5), Bob Carter (2-05), and Phil Parthemore (2-0-5)
did their share. Cowan, with 15
goals and 24 assists, was, as of
Tuesday, second in the state in
total points; Kneip (21 and 4)
was seventh, while tied with
Washington's Jim Chalfant and
Carl Ortman in the former department.
The Hopkins midfield situation, while hardly as marked bY
injuries as in previous weeks, still
has a slightly unsettled look.
Wayne Towns is the only regular
who definitely will not see action,
but the'second and third contingents—bothered by a variety of
nagging injuries—are uncertain.
Scott commented on the good
performances turned in by members (Steve Latson, Will Scroggs,
Wes Bachur. and Parthemore) of
these two groups in past weeks.
